elements.content: Four new Mn(II) coordination polymers [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(C6H5COO)2] n (1), [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n (2), [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n (3), and [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n (4) (where 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine) have been synthesized by self-assembly of the primary ligands, benzoate and the o-, m-, and p-isomers of nitrobenzoates, respectively, together with 4,4′-bpy as the secondary spacer. All four complexes were characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses, and variable-temperature magnetic measurements. The structural analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 3 are constructed by linear fused chains through double syn-syn (for 1) or syn-anti (for 3) carboxylate-bridged Mn(II), which are further linked to one another by trans coordinated 4,4′-bpy bridges, giving rise to a rectangular grid-like two-dimensional (2D) net. Complex 2 features one-dimensional (1D) molecular ladder formed by both syn-syn and syn-anti carboxylate-bridged dimeric Mn(II) units which are joined alternately by 4,4′-bpy. Complex 4 is formed by fused zigzag chains of double syn-syn carboxylate-bridged Mn(II) that are connected by cis oriented 4,4′-bpy to generate an unprecedented three-dimensional (3D) framework. The dimensionality of the complexes thus varies from 1D to 2D to 3D on changing the position of the nitro group from o- to m- to p- in the benzoate, showing explicitly the tuning ability of this apparently innocent substituent on the topology of the coordination polymer. Variable-temperature (1.8–300 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements showed the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling in all four complexes that have been fitted with an infinite classical-spin chain model derived by Fisher for 1, 3, and 4 (J = −0.779(2), −0.855(2), and −0.536(2) cm–1, respectively) and van Vleck equation for 2 (J = −0.354(2) cm–1).

elements.content: Four new coordination polymers of Mn(II), constructed by 4,4′-bipyridine and benzoate or isomeric o-, m-, and p-nitrobenzoate, have been synthesized and characterized structurally and magnetically. The apparently innocent −NO2 group exhibits a striking effect on the structure and dimensionality of the resulting coordination polymers from a one-dimensional ladder to two-dimensional grid to three-dimensional framework with the shift of its position from ortho to meta to para.
elements.clean_text: Four new coordination polymers of Mn(II), constructed by 4,4'-bipyridine and benzoate or isomeric o-, m-, and p-nitrobenzoate, have been synthesized and characterized structurally and magnetically. The apparently innocent -NO2 group exhibits a striking effect on the structure and dimensionality of the resulting coordination polymers from a one-dimensional ladder to two-dimensional grid to three-dimensional framework with the shift of its position from ortho to meta to para.

elements.content: Current interest in the crystal engineering of coordination polymers is rapidly expanding due not only to their potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, magnetism, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, and sensors but also to their intriguing structural architectures and topologies. Despite the upsurge in the construction of diverse architectures, the control of dimensionality is still a major challenge in this field due to the fact that the network topologies based on molecular building blocks are usually controlled and modified by the selection of the coordination geometry of the central metal, the structural chemistry of organic ligands, the character of solvent used, and the ratio of metal salt to organic ligand. Nevertheless, many new reaction systems can still be elaborately designed so as to explore the important relationships between various synthetic factors and the structural topologies of the coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Current interest in the crystal engineering of coordination polymers is rapidly expanding due not only to their potential applications in catalysis, adsorption, magnetism, molecular recognition, nonlinear optics, and sensors but also to their intriguing structural architectures and topologies. Despite the upsurge in the construction of diverse architectures, the control of dimensionality is still a major challenge in this field due to the fact that the network topologies based on molecular building blocks are usually controlled and modified by the selection of the coordination geometry of the central metal, the structural chemistry of organic ligands, the character of solvent used, and the ratio of metal salt to organic ligand. Nevertheless, many new reaction systems can still be elaborately designed so as to explore the important relationships between various synthetic factors and the structural topologies of the coordination polymers.

elements.content: In particular, the manganese-based coordination compounds have received considerable interest in the fields of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering not only for their remarkable magnetochemical properties but also for their rich biochemistry. Furthermore, because of their low cost and toxicity, manganese coordination compounds are growing in importance as homogeneous catalysts. It is well-known that by the judicious choice of the organic spacer and the central metal, it is possible to elaborate a specific architecture and even to create expected properties related to the architecture. Since long, neutral, rigid N-donor ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) have been widely used to construct supramolecular architectures along with various anionic species that compensate the charge of the resulting metal–organic frameworks, and this has become an interesting strategy to construct neutral nanoporous coordination polymers. Carboxylate groups that can display a wide variety of coordination modes such as terminal (Scheme a), chelating (Scheme b,c), bridging (syn-syn (Scheme d), syn-anti (Scheme e), anti-anti (Scheme f)) are one of the most widely used bridging ligands for designing polynuclear complexes with interesting structures and topologies. A wide variety of manganese complexes containing various carboxylate ligands as well as their metal–organic frameworks with 4,4′-bpy have been constructed. It has been observed that interesting variation in their topologies of the network can be introduced by changing the alkyl/aryl group of the carboxylate.

Since long, neutral, rigid N-donor ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bpy) have been widely used to construct supramolecular architectures along with various anionic species that compensate the charge of the resulting metal-organic frameworks, and this has become an interesting strategy to construct neutral nanoporous coordination polymers. Carboxylate groups that can display a wide variety of coordination modes such as terminal (Scheme a), chelating (Scheme b,c), bridging (syn-syn (Scheme d), syn-anti (Scheme e), anti-anti (Scheme f)) are one of the most widely used bridging ligands for designing polynuclear complexes with interesting structures and topologies. A wide variety of manganese complexes containing various carboxylate ligands as well as their metal-organic frameworks with 4,4'-bpy have been constructed. It has been observed that interesting variation in their topologies of the network can be introduced by changing the alkyl/aryl group of the carboxylate.

elements.clean_text: 1  Different Coordination Modes of Carboxylate Group Observed in the Literature

elements.content: We would like to explore if an apparently innocent substitution in the phenyl ring of benzoate ion can bring about any change in the molecular architecture of their Mn(II) complexes with 4,4′-bpy. For this purpose, we use here benzoate and o-, m-, and p-nitrobenzoates. A few similar studies were undertaken by several groups. For example, Ma et al. reported different architectures by using isomeric phthalate and Feng et al. designed a group of coordination polymers exploiting the cis and trans conformation of maleic and fumaric acid, respectively. The observed structural variations are not surprising in these complexes as the coordinating carboxylate groups change their relative positions. Corbella et al. reported a series of compounds with different nuclearities formed by the isomers of chlorobenzoate and 1,10-phenanthroline or 2,2′-bipyridine. However, in these reports the effects of changing the solvents and the metal to ligand ratios were more obvious than the effect of the positional change of the chloro substitution. To understand the effect of noncoordinating substituents on molecular architectures, it is desirable to synthesize the compounds under similar reaction conditions with the identical ratios of the reactants.

For this purpose, we use here benzoate and o-, m-, and p-nitrobenzoates. A few similar studies were undertaken by several groups. The observed structural variations are not surprising in these complexes as the coordinating carboxylate groups change their relative positions. Corbella et al. reported a series of compounds with different nuclearities formed by the isomers of chlorobenzoate and 1,10-phenanthroline or 2,2'-bipyridine. However, in these reports the effects of changing the solvents and the metal to ligand ratios were more obvious than the effect of the positional change of the chloro substitution. To understand the effect of noncoordinating substituents on molecular architectures, it is desirable to synthesize the compounds under similar reaction conditions with the identical ratios of the reactants.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis, single crystal X-ray structures, and magnetic behaviors of four manganese(II) polymers [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(C6H5COO)2] n (1), [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n (2), [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n (3), and [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n (4) (where 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine). The complexes have been synthesized under identical ambient conditions. An interesting structural variation from 1D ladder (2) to 2D sheet (1 and 3) to 3D network (4) is observed in the complexes by introducing the nitro substituent in the ortho, meta, or para position of the benzoate group. To the best of our knowledge, among the complexes of Mn(II) with 4,4′-bpy and monocarboxylate ions, very few possess similar 1D ladder and 2D sheet structures, and only one of them has been characterized structurally and magnetically whereas the 3D topology of complex 4 is unprecedented to date.

The complexes have been synthesized under identical ambient conditions. An interesting structural variation from 1D ladder (2) to 2D sheet (1 and 3) to 3D network (4) is observed in the complexes by introducing the nitro substituent in the ortho, meta, or para position of the benzoate group. To the best of our knowledge, among the complexes of Mn(II) with 4,4'-bpy and monocarboxylate ions, very few possess similar 1D ladder and 2D sheet structures, and only one of them has been characterized structurally and magnetically whereas the 3D topology of complex 4 is unprecedented to date.

elements.content: All four metal carboxylate salts, that is, Mn(C6H5COO)2·4H2O, Mn(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·H2O, Mn(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·2H2O, and Mn(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·4H2O, were synthesized by the procedures described previously. All other chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Starting Materials

All four metal carboxylate salts, that is, Mn(C6H5COO)2⋅4H2O, Mn(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2⋅H2O, Mn(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2⋅2H2O, and Mn(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2⋅4H2O, were synthesized by the procedures described previously. All other chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification.

elements.content: A 10 mL methanol solution of 0.820 g (5 mmol) of 4,4′-bpy was added dropwise to a stirred solution of 1.845 g (5 mmol) of Mn(C6H5COO)2·4H2O in 20 mL of CH3OH. After ca. 15 min, yellow colored solid products started to separate. The solid was filtered off after about 2 h and from the clear filtrate pale yellow platelike crystals were grown by slow evaporation at room temperature for 2–3 days.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(C6H5COO)2] n  (1), [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n  (2), [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n  (3), and [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2] n  (4)

A 10 mL methanol solution of 0.820 g (5 mmol) of 4,4'-bpy was added dropwise to a stirred solution of 1.845 g (5 mmol) of Mn(C6H5COO)2⋅4H2O in 20 mL of CH3OH. After ca. 15 min, yellow colored solid products started to separate. The solid was filtered off after about 2 h and from the clear filtrate pale yellow platelike crystals were grown by slow evaporation at room temperature for 2-3 days.

elements.content: Complexes 2, 3, and 4 were obtained by following a procedure similar to that of 1 by using Mn(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·H2O (2.025 g, 5 mmol), Mn(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·2H2O (2.115 g, 5 mmol), and Mn(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·4H2O (2.295 g, 5 mmol), respectively, in place of Mn(C6H5COO)2·4H2O.

Complex 3: Yield: 1.92 g; 71%. Anal. Calcd for C24H16MnN4O8 (543.35): C, 53.05; H, 2.97; N, 10.31 Found: C, 53.00; H, 2.95; N, 10.29. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1601 νas(COO), 1388 νs(COO).

Complex 4: Yield: 1.87 g; 69%. Anal. Calcd for C24H16MnN4O8 (543.35): C, 53.05; H, 2.97; N, 10.31 Found: C, 53.03; H, 2.91; N, 10.26. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1667 νas(COO), 1397 νs(COO).

Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. IR spectra in KBr (4500–500 cm–1) were recorded using a Perkin-Elmer RXI FT-IR spectrophotometer. The magnetic susceptibilities on polycrystalline samples of 1–4 were measured on a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMS-7) at applied magnetic fields of 5000 Oe in a temperature range of 1.8–300 K. Typical sample masses were 20–50 mg. The magnetic response was corrected with diamagnetic blank data of the sample holder obtained separately. The diamagnetic contribution of the sample itself was estimated from Pascal’s constant.

Physical Measurements

The magnetic susceptibilities on polycrystalline samples of 1-4 were measured on a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer (MPMS-7) at applied magnetic fields of 5000 Oe in a temperature range of 1.8-300 K. The diamagnetic contribution of the sample itself was estimated from Pascal's constant.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of each complex were mounted on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo–Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The crystals were positioned at 60 mm from the CCD. 360 frames were measured with a counting time of 10 s. The structures were solved using Patterson method by using the SHELXS97. Subsequent difference Fourier synthesis and least-squares refinement revealed the positions of the remaining non-hydrogen atoms. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with independent anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and their displacement parameters were fixed to be 1.2 times larger than those of the attached non-hydrogen atom. Successful convergence was indicated by the maximum shift/error of 0.001 for the last cycle of the least-squares refinement. Absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. All calculations were carried out using SHELXS 97, SHELXL 97, PLATON 99, ORTEP-32, and WinGX systemVer-1.64. Data collection and structure refinement parameters and crystallographic data for the four complexes are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

Suitable single crystals of each complex were mounted on a Bruker SMART diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator and Mo-Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation. The crystals were positioned at 60 mm from the CCD. 360 frames were measured with a counting time of 10 s. The structures were solved using Patterson method by using the SHELXS97. Subsequent difference Fourier synthesis and least-squares refinement revealed the positions of the remaining non-hydrogen atoms. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with independent anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and their displacement parameters were fixed to be 1.2 times larger than those of the attached non-hydrogen atom. Successful convergence was indicated by the maximum shift/error of 0.001 for the last cycle of the least-squares refinement. Absorption corrections were carried out using the SADABS program. All calculations were carried out using SHELXS 97, SHELXL 97, PLATON 99, ORTEP-32, and WinGX systemVer-1.64. Data collection and structure refinement parameters and crystallographic data for the four complexes are given in Table .

The four coordination polymers have been synthesized under the same conditions: the Mn(II) salts of respective acids, Mn(C6H5COO)2·4H2O, Mn(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·H2O, Mn(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·2H2O, or Mn(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2·4H2O were allowed to react with 4,4′-bpy in methanol solution at ambient temperature in a 1:1 molar ratio when the products 1–4 form smoothly and start to separate as a light-yellow crystalline solid in a very similar way. All four compounds were formed by self-assembly of the primary ligands, benzoate or the respective nitrobenzoates together with 4,4′-bpy as the secondary spacer. The stoichiometry of all four products are the same with the general formula [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(C6H4(X)COO)2] n (X = H for 1, o-NO2 for 2, m-NO2 for 3, and p-NO2 for 4), yet their structures and dimensionalities are very different as shown in Scheme . Compounds 1 and 3, which are synthesized by using benzoate and m-nitrobenzoate, respectively, are 2D sheets; o-Nitrobenzoate yields compound 2 that has a one-dimensional ladder structure, whereas compound 4 obtained from p-nitrobenzoate is a 3D polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The four coordination polymers have been synthesized under the same conditions: the Mn(II) salts of respective acids, Mn(C6H5COO)2⋅4H2O, Mn(o-(NO2)C6H4COO)2⋅H2O, Mn(m-(NO2)C6H4COO)2⋅2H2O, or Mn(p-(NO2)C6H4COO)2⋅4H2O were allowed to react with 4,4'-bpy in methanol solution at ambient temperature in a 1:1 molar ratio when the products 1-4 form smoothly and start to separate as a light-yellow crystalline solid in a very similar way. All four compounds were formed by self-assembly of the primary ligands, benzoate or the respective nitrobenzoates together with 4,4'-bpy as the secondary spacer. The stoichiometry of all four products are the same with the general formula [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(C6H4(X)COO)2] n  (X = H for 1, o-NO2 for 2, m-NO2 for 3, and p-NO2 for 4), yet their structures and dimensionalities are very different as shown in Scheme . Compounds 1 and 3, which are synthesized by using benzoate and m-nitrobenzoate, respectively, are 2D sheets; o-Nitrobenzoate yields compound 2 that has a one-dimensional ladder structure, whereas compound 4 obtained from p-nitrobenzoate is a 3D polymer.

elements.content: Spectroscopic data and their assignments are given in the . The attributions of IR spectra of all the complexes are difficult due to the appearance of several absorption bands from the secondary spacer 4,4′-bpy and the benzoate/nitro-benzoate ligands. Assignments are based on the structures of 1–4 and related complexes reported previously. In the region expected for the νas(COO–) absorption, compounds 1, 3, and 4 exhibit one single sharp and strong band at 1642, 1601, and 1667 cm–1 respectively, attributable to the presence of only one type of carboxylate bridging in the structures. While for the molecular ladder complex 2, two sharp and strong bands at 1621 and 1531 cm–1 indicate the presence of two different coordination modes of carboxylate groups. Along with these, the sharp peaks at 1392 cm–1 (for 1), 1405 cm–1 along with a shoulder at 1365 cm–1 (for 2), 1388 cm–1 (for 3), and 1397 cm–1 (for 4) appear due to the characteristic symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylates.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectra of the Complexes

Spectroscopic data and their assignments are given in the . The attributions of IR spectra of all the complexes are difficult due to the appearance of several absorption bands from the secondary spacer 4,4'-bpy and the benzoate/nitro-benzoate ligands. Assignments are based on the structures of 1-4 and related complexes reported previously. In the region expected for the νas(COO-) absorption, compounds 1, 3, and 4 exhibit one single sharp and strong band at 1642, 1601, and 1667 cm-1 respectively, attributable to the presence of only one type of carboxylate bridging in the structures. While for the molecular ladder complex 2, two sharp and strong bands at 1621 and 1531 cm-1 indicate the presence of two different coordination modes of carboxylate groups. Along with these, the sharp peaks at 1392 cm-1 (for 1), 1405 cm-1 along with a shoulder at 1365 cm-1 (for 2), 1388 cm-1 (for 3), and 1397 cm-1 (for 4) appear due to the characteristic symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylates.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 3 are very similar, the only difference being that of the carboxylate group, benzoate for 1 and m-nitrobenzoate for 3. The 2D sheet structures of both compounds consist of double μ1,3-carboxylate-bridged (1κO:2κO′) chains of Mn(II) ion along the crystallographic c-axis, which are connected by 4,4′-bpy bridge along the b-axis. In both structures, as shown in Figure , the manganese(II) ion is six-coordinate in a distorted octahedral environment and sits on a 2-fold axis that bisects the pyridine rings of the 4,4′-bpy ligands. The equatorial plane contains four oxygen donors, O1, O2, O1a, and O2a from four different carboxylate groups with Mn–O(1) and Mn–O(2) distances of 2.179(2) and 2.129(2) Å in 1 and 2.145(3) and 2.168(4) Å in 3, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structure of Complexes 1 and 3 

The structures of 1 and 3 are very similar, the only difference being that of the carboxylate group, benzoate for 1 and m-nitrobenzoate for 3. The 2D sheet structures of both compounds consist of double μ1,3-carboxylate-bridged (1κO:2κO') chains of Mn(II) ion along the crystallographic c-axis, which are connected by 4,4'-bpy bridge along the b-axis. In both structures, as shown in Figure , the manganese(II) ion is six-coordinate in a distorted octahedral environment and sits on a 2-fold axis that bisects the pyridine rings of the 4,4'-bpy ligands. The equatorial plane contains four oxygen donors, O1, O2, O1a, and O2a from four different carboxylate groups with Mn-O(1) and Mn-O(2) distances of 2.179(2) and 2.129(2) Å in 1 and 2.145(3) and 2.168(4) Å in 3, respectively.

All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The root mean squared (r.m.s.) deviations of the four basal donor atoms from their mean planes around Mn(1) are 0.049 and 0.064 Å, and the Mn(1) ions deviate from their respective mean planes by 0.083(1) and 0.124(1) Å, for 1 and 3, respectively. The two trans axial positions are occupied by two bipyridyl nitrogen donors with Mn–N(1) and Mn–N(2) at distances of 2.294(4) and 2.297(4) Å for 1 and 2.304(5) and 2.304(5) Å for 3, respectively. Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table . The other oxygen atom of each carboxylate ions coordinates to a neighboring manganese ion Mn1a or Mn1b to complete the 1κO:2κO′ bridging mode and thus forms an eight-membered ring. As a result of repetition of this eight-membered ring, an almost linear chain of doubly carboxylate-briged Mn(II) is formed along the c axis with the Mna–Mn–Mnb angles of 153.21(2)° and 161.84(4)° for 1 and 3, respectively, as shown in Figure (for compound 1) and S1 (, for compound 3)). The torsion angles, (O1a–C7–O2–Mn1, −1.3(5)° and O2–C7–O1a–Mn1a, −80.9(4)° for 1 (a = symmetry element –x, 1 – y, 2 – z) and O2–C1–O1–Mn1b, −36.9(7)° (b = symmetry element –x, –y, 2 – z) and O1–C1–O2–Mn1, 111.5(5)° for 3) show that the carboxylate bridge is syn-syn in 1 but syn-anti in 3, and this difference in bridging modes of carboxylate seems to be responsible for the shorter interatomic Mn···Mn distance of 4.876(6) Å in 1 compared to 5.044(3) Å in 3. In 3, the Mn–Oanti distance (2.168(4) Å) is longer than Mn–Osyn distances (2.145(3) Å), and this trend is usual for such complexes.

elements.content: These chains are further linked by trans axially coordinated μ-4,4′-bpy to form a 2D grid-like network along the bc plane as shown in Figure (right) for 1 and Figure S2 () for 3. In the case of compound 1, the pyridine rings of μ-4,4′-bpy are twisted by 38.8(2)° and the bridged Mn–Mn distance along μ-4,4′-bpy is 11.691 Å. Therefore, the grid dimension in the layer is 11.691 Å × 4.876 Å, whereas the pyridine rings of μ-4,4′-bpy linking two Mn ions are much more twisted at 63.7(2)° in 3 and the grid dimension in the layer (11.676 Å × 5.044 Å) is slightly larger than that in complex 1.

Therefore, the grid dimension in the layer is 11.691 Å × 4.876 Å, whereas the pyridine rings of μ-4,4'-bpy linking two Mn ions are much more twisted at 63.7(2)° in 3 and the grid dimension in the layer (11.676 Å × 5.044 Å) is slightly larger than that in complex 1.

elements.content: There are numerous examples of coordination polymers of Mn(II) where polycarboxylate ions and 4,4′-bpy group act as bridging ligands. Use of monocarboxylate ion along with 4,4′-bpy to construct polynuclear Mn(II) complexes is relatively rare, and among these complexes only three are found where the doubly carboxylate-bridged chains of Mn(II) are connected by 4,4′-bipyridine to result in a 2D polymeric sheet like in 1 and 3.
elements.clean_text: There are numerous examples of coordination polymers of Mn(II) where polycarboxylate ions and 4,4'-bpy group act as bridging ligands. Use of monocarboxylate ion along with 4,4'-bpy to construct polynuclear Mn(II) complexes is relatively rare, and among these complexes only three are found where the doubly carboxylate-bridged chains of Mn(II) are connected by 4,4'-bipyridine to result in a 2D polymeric sheet like in 1 and 3.

elements.content:
Complex 2 features a one-dimensional coordination polymer with a ladder-like structure as shown in Figure together with the atomic numbering scheme.

There are two crystallographically different Mn(II) ions in complex 2. Both Mn(1) and Mn(2) centers adopt similar hexa-coordinated environment, but the bond lengths and bond angles around them are slightly different. Selected bond lengths and angles are summarized in Table . Each Mn atom is coordinated by a chelating bidentate o-nitrobenzoate which forms a four-membered chelate ring with a bite angle of 56.43(6)° for Mn(1) and 58.52(6)° for Mn(2). Both Mn(1) and Mn(2) are linked to their respective centrosymmetrically related atoms Mn(1)a and Mn(2)b (symmetry operation a = –x, −y, −z (for Mn1) and b = –x – 1, –y, –z + 1 (for Mn2)) via two carboxylate bridges to make a dinuclear [Mn2(C6H4(o-NO2)CO2)4] core. The bridging modes of the carboxylate groups are strikingly different at the two Mn centers; they are syn-syn with torsion angles of −7.3(3)° (O13a–C1–O14–Mn1) and −6.5(10)° (O14a–C1a–O13–Mn1) between Mn(1) and Mn(1)a but syn-anti with torsion angles of −27.7(3)o (O15b–C8b–O16–Mn2) and 115.2(4)° (O16b–C8–O15–Mn2) between Mn(2) and Mn(2)b. The interatomic Mn···Mn distance between Mn(2) centers (4.503(6) Å) is expectedly longer than that between Mn(1) centers (4.088(6) Å). Between the two Mn–O distances around Mn(2) centers, the shorter distance (2.098(2) Å) correspond to Oanti, while the larger one (2.133(2) Å) corresponds to Osyn which is rather exceptional but has also been observed in some acetate- and benzoate-bridged complexes. The Mn–O distances of this bridging carboxylate (2.098(2)–2.143(2) Å) are comparable to those of 1 and 3 but are significantly shorter than those of the chelated ones (2.207(2)–2.402(2) Å). The root mean squared (r.m.s.) deviations of the four basal donor atoms from their mean planes around Mn(1) and Mn(2) are 0.147 and 0.024 Å, respectively. The Mn(1) and Mn(2) ions deviate from their respective mean planes by 0.032(1) and 0.071(1) Å, respectively. The chelating carboxylate which is a part of the equatorial plane makes the coordination geometry of the Mn(II) atom severely distorted from ideal octahedron due to the small bite angle. This small bite angle seems also responsible for the much wider O(13)–Mn(1)–O(14) and O(15)–Mn(2)–O(16) angles (124.24(7) and 107.81(7) Å, respectively) in the eight-membered ring formed by the two bridging carboxylates with Mn atoms in 2 compare to those in 1 and 3 (93.90(8) and 90.20(12) Ǻ respectively). The 4,4′-bpy ligands occupy the two trans axial positions with Mn–N bond lengths in the ranges of 2.265(2)–2.305(2) Å, and link adjacent dinuclear cores of alternating Mn(1) and Mn(2) atoms to form a 1D coordination polymer which extends along the b-direction (Figure ). This creates a molecular ladder with the dimer serving as the rungs and the 4,4′-bpy ligands as the uprights. The pyridine rings of the two independent μ-4,4′-bpy linking two Mn ions are twisted by 21.8(1) and 23.6(1)° for the two ligands containing N1 and N2, and N3 and N4, respectively. It is to be mentioned that despite the prevalence of coordination polymers of first row transition metal ions containing 4,4′-bpy and carboxylate ligands, the molecular ladders are relatively rare. With Mn(II), only one very similar ladder structure formed by acetate and 4,4′-bipy has been reported. The dimensions of complex 2 are very similar to those of the reported one.

elements.content: Complex 4 is a 3D coordination polymer. The geometry around the Mn(II) is distorted octahedron, and the coordinating atoms are the same as in 1 and 3 but their relative positions are different. In this complex, the Mn atom sits on a 2-fold axis passing between the two bipyridyl ligands. The equatorial plane is defined by three oxygen donors from three p-nitrobenzoate groups and one bipyridyl nitrogen, whereas one pyridyl nitrogen of other bipyridyl linker and one oxygen atom from another p-nitrobenzoate occupy axial positions as shown in Figure together with the atomic numbering scheme. The r.m.s. deviation of the four basal donor atoms from their mean plane around Mn(1) is 0.061 Å. The Mn(1) ions deviate from their respective mean plane by 0.170(1) Å.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structure of Complex 4 

Complex 4 is a 3D coordination polymer. The geometry around the Mn(II) is distorted octahedron, and the coordinating atoms are the same as in 1 and 3 but their relative positions are different. In this complex, the Mn atom sits on a 2-fold axis passing between the two bipyridyl ligands. The equatorial plane is defined by three oxygen donors from three p-nitrobenzoate groups and one bipyridyl nitrogen, whereas one pyridyl nitrogen of other bipyridyl linker and one oxygen atom from another p-nitrobenzoate occupy axial positions as shown in Figure  together with the atomic numbering scheme. The r.m.s. deviation of the four basal donor atoms from their mean plane around Mn(1) is 0.061 Å. The Mn(1) ions deviate from their respective mean plane by 0.170(1) Å.

elements.content: Here the neighboring Mn atoms are connected through the double syn-syn 1κO:2κO′ bridging carboxylate groups with torsion angles of −52.9(6)° (O4c–C12c–O3a–Mn1) and 28.5(4)° (O3–C12b–O4b–Mn1b)) forming an eight-membered ring but as one of the oxygen atoms coordinates to an axial position, the mean plane of the two eight-membered rings around an Mn(II) ion become nearly perpendicular. This results in a doubly carboxylate-bridged zigzag chain of Mn(II) that runs parallel to c axis with Mna–Mn–Mnb angle of 102.53(3)° (Figure a). The interatomic Mn···Mn distance between Mn centers is 4.723(1) Å, which falls in the range of distances reported for similar compounds.

elements.content: A CSD search reveals that a chloroacetate-bridged and a chlorobenzoate-bridged Mn(II) complex where 1,10-phenanthroline is chelated to the metal centers [CCDC Nos. 156274 and 735802] possess a doubly carboxylate-bridged zigzag 1D chain similar to that of complex 4. Such orientation attained as 1,10-phenanthroline has to span cis positions to the metal center. Among the coordination polymers of Mn(II), the 4,4′-bpy ligands usually coordinate to the trans positions of Mn(II) and propagate the polynuclar chain in a particular direction as in 1 and 3. There are some examples in which the 4,4′-bpy coordinate to the cis positions and extend the polymeric structure in two different directions. However, the topology of 4 is unprecedented, as no compound of Mn(II) in which the doubly carboxylate-bridged chain and the two cis-coordinated 4,4′-bpy molecules propagate in three different directions to generate 3D grid structure is reported until date. In a related 3D [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(HCOO)2] n complex, the anti-anti formate bridge does not produce any zigzag chain, rather gives a diamond topology which is further linked to two N-atoms from two trans coordinated 4,4′-bpy ligands, resulting the three-dimensional adamantine-type cage.
elements.clean_text: A CSD search reveals that a chloroacetate-bridged and a chlorobenzoate-bridged Mn(II) complex where 1,10-phenanthroline is chelated to the metal centers [CCDC Nos. 156274 and 735802] possess a doubly carboxylate-bridged zigzag 1D chain similar to that of complex 4. Such orientation attained as 1,10-phenanthroline has to span cis positions to the metal center. Among the coordination polymers of Mn(II), the 4,4'-bpy ligands usually coordinate to the trans positions of Mn(II) and propagate the polynuclar chain in a particular direction as in 1 and 3. There are some examples in which the 4,4'-bpy coordinate to the cis positions and extend the polymeric structure in two different directions. However, the topology of 4 is unprecedented, as no compound of Mn(II) in which the doubly carboxylate-bridged chain and the two cis-coordinated 4,4'-bpy molecules propagate in three different directions to generate 3D grid structure is reported until date. In a related 3D [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(HCOO)2] n  complex, the anti-anti formate bridge does not produce any zigzag chain, rather gives a diamond topology which is further linked to two N-atoms from two trans coordinated 4,4'-bpy ligands, resulting the three-dimensional adamantine-type cage.

elements.content: It is worth comparing the structures of compounds 1–4. In compound 1 the ligand is benzoate and it forms a 2D polymeric sheet structure in which the doubly benzoate-bridged chains of Mn(II) are linked by trans-coordinated 4,4′-bpy. In 2, the carboxylate ligand is o-nitrobenzoate and the doubly carboxylate-bridged chain is terminated just after two Mn(II) ions by a chelating o-nitrobenzoate resulting the molecular ladder. The use of m-nitrobenzoate produces again the same sheet structure as the benzoate. The p-nitrobenzoate, on the other hand, generates a 3D coordination polymer where the carboxylate chains are linked by cis-coordinated 4,4′-bpy. There is neither a significant nor periodic change in Mn–O bond lengths due to the nitro substitution. However, it is interesting to note that in complex 2 the nitro group of the o-nitrobenzoate is involved in l.p.···π interactions and in 4 the p-nitro group has l.p.···π interactions with the phenyl group of neighboring chains which are linked by 4,4′-bpy. Additionally, there are significant C–H···π interactions in 2, whereas no such interactions are found in 1 or 3. Therefore, it may be suggested that weak forces such as l.p.···π, C–H···π interactions play an important role in stabilizing the different topologies.

In 2, the carboxylate ligand is o-nitrobenzoate and the doubly carboxylate-bridged chain is terminated just after two Mn(II) ions by a chelating o-nitrobenzoate resulting the molecular ladder. The use of m-nitrobenzoate produces again the same sheet structure as the benzoate. The p-nitrobenzoate, on the other hand, generates a 3D coordination polymer where the carboxylate chains are linked by cis-coordinated 4,4'-bpy. There is neither a significant nor periodic change in Mn-O bond lengths due to the nitro substitution. However, it is interesting to note that in complex 2 the nitro group of the o-nitrobenzoate is involved in l.p.⋅⋅⋅π interactions and in 4 the p-nitro group has l.p.⋅⋅⋅π interactions with the phenyl group of neighboring chains which are linked by 4,4'-bpy. Additionally, there are significant C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions in 2, whereas no such interactions are found in 1 or 3. Therefore, it may be suggested that weak forces such as l.p.⋅⋅⋅π, C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions play an important role in stabilizing the different topologies.

elements.content: We measured the magnetic properties of 1–4 on a SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.5 T. The temperature dependences of χm T and χm –1 are shown in Figure . In a high temperature region (≥ca. 20 K), the data obeyed the empirical Curie–Weiss law, χm = C/(T – θ), where C and θ stand for the Curie and Weiss constants, respectively. The optimized parameters are listed in Table . The C values (4.351(4)–4.536(3) cm3 K mol–1) are close to the spin-only value of χm T = 4.375 cm3 K mol–1 expected from high-spin d5 (S = 5/2) configuration and g = 2. In other words, the g values of 1–4 calculated from the Curie constants fell in 1.99–2.03, as usually observed for high-spin Mn2+ compounds. On cooling, the χm T values monotonically decreased, indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling, and the θ values were negative. The θ value of 2 (−4.5(2) K) was somewhat smaller in magnitude than those of 1, 3, and 4.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Study for Compounds 1-4 

We measured the magnetic properties of 1-4 on a SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.5 T. The temperature dependences of χm T and χm -1 are shown in Figure . In a high temperature region (≥ca. 20 K), the data obeyed the empirical Curie-Weiss law, χm = C/(T - θ), where C and θ stand for the Curie and Weiss constants, respectively. The optimized parameters are listed in Table . The C values (4.351(4)-4.536(3) cm3 K mol-1) are close to the spin-only value of χm T = 4.375 cm3 K mol-1 expected from high-spin d5 (S = 5/2) configuration and g = 2. In other words, the g values of 1-4 calculated from the Curie constants fell in 1.99-2.03, as usually observed for high-spin Mn2+ compounds. On cooling, the χm T values monotonically decreased, indicating the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling, and the θ values were negative. The θ value of 2 (-4.5(2) K) was somewhat smaller in magnitude than those of 1, 3, and 4.

elements.content: To evaluate the exchange coupling, we have to identify the dominant interaction pathways, in the metal–organic framework. In the crystal lattices of 1, 3, and 4, the Mn(II) ions are doubly bridged with three atoms of the carboxylate groups, and this motif is repeated infinitely. The most important exchange coupling can be assigned to intrachain Mn···Mn with equal spacing. The chains are connected with 4,4′-bpy, which may afford auxiliary interaction because of the long distance (across eight atoms).

The chains are connected with 4,4'-bpy, which may afford auxiliary interaction because of the long distance (across eight atoms).

elements.content: The parameters were optimized by using all of the data (1.8–300 K) to give J/k B = −0.771(2) to −1.230(3) K for 1, 3, and 4 (Table ). The calculated curve almost reproduced the experimental data (the solid lines in Figure a,c,d).
elements.clean_text: The parameters were optimized by using all of the data (1.8-300 K) to give J/k B = -0.771(2) to -1.230(3) K for 1, 3, and 4 (Table ). The calculated curve almost reproduced the experimental data (the solid lines in Figure a,c,d).

elements.content: Compound 2 consists of dinuclear motifs with doubly carboxylate bridges, and these units are connected with 4,4′-bipyridine. The observed antiferromagnetic coupling can be attributed mainly to the Mn-(O–CO)2-Mn moiety as a dinuclear magnetic cluster. There are two crystallographically independent dinuclear clusters in 2, and the following analyses imply the average of the two contributions. We utilized the van Vleck equation (eq ) with x = J/k B T from the Heisenberg spin-Hamiltonian, H = −2J S 1·S 2. The parameters were optimized as J/k B = −0.509(2) K and g = 1.980(1) (Table ). elements.content: For the three atoms (μ1,3‑) carboxylate bridges, a syn-anti bridging configuration is rare by comparison with a syn-syn configuration. It is expected on the basis of the respective geometries that an efficient overlap between the 3d magnetic orbital of the Mn2+ center and the 2p orbital of the carboxyl oxygen atom would lead to weak and antiferromagnetic interaction through the μ1,3-carboxylate bridging ligand and depends on the coordination mode of the carboxylate ligand. A syn-syn pattern usually provides small metal–metal distances and a good overlap of magnetic orbitals and consequently induces stronger antiferromagnetic coupling. Syn-anti carboxylato bridges induce smaller J values because of the expanded metallic core and a mismatch in the orientation of magnetic orbitals. However, these are not the definitive controlling factors; rather the magnetic interaction through a carboxylate bridge should be very sensitive to small structural changes. The relative orientations of two magnetic orbitals taking part in the superexchange could be affected by several factors: the Mn–O distance, the O–Mn–O angle (α), and the Mn–O–C angles (β/γ). Small changes in these parameters could also change the overlap through the carboxylate group.

elements.content: Table shows some structural parameters for these compounds in comparison with analogous compounds described in the literature. From the table, it may be suggested that the Mn–Osyn (in case of syn-syn mode the shorter Mn–Osyn) distance and the corresponding Mn–Osyn–C angle (β) are the two most important factors that control the magnitude of antiferromagnetic coupling. In general, shorter Mn–Osyn distance and smaller β favor stronger antiferromagnetic coupling. For example, in the present compounds the structural analyses reveal that the carboxylate bridge is syn-syn in 1 but syn-anti in 3 and owing only to this difference in bridging modes of carboxylate the J value of 1 should be greater than 3. In practice, the magnitude of coupling constant of 3 (−0.855(2) cm–1) is slightly greater than that of 1 (−0.779(2) cm–1). The Mn–Osyn distance of 2.129 Å in 1 is slightly shorter than that (2.145 Å) in 3, but β (147.24°) in 1 is greater than in 3 (139.89°). These two opposing effects make the J values comparable. In complex 4, the Mn–Osyn distance of 2.131 Å is intermediate between those of 1 and 3, but the larger β (153.81°) seems to be responsible for lower J (−0.536(2) cm–1). In complex 2, the situation is much more complicated due to the presence of two crystallographically different Mn(II) centers, one of which is syn-syn and the other is syn-anti carboxylate-bridged. The av. Mn–Osyn distance (2.121 Å) is slightly shorter than those in the other three complexes. The av β (144.28°) is comparable to that of other three, but the one associated with the syn-syn bridge is very high (169.06°). Moreover, the Osyn–Mn–Osyn/anti (α) angles, which are comparable in 1, 3, and 4 but are relatively large in 2, probably contribute also to the small J value of 2 (−0.354(2) cm–1). From the magnetostructural correlation, we can conclude that the magnitude of J is sensitive both to Mn–Osyn bond distances and to the α and β angles. This is not surprising as the Mn–Osyn bond should be the most effective superexchange pathway for coupling and the importance of β for such bridges has been established. In the present complexes the Mn–Osyn bond distances hardly vary and the coupling constants seem to be controlled mostly by the β angles. On the other hand, the through-space interaction is a minor factor for the antiferromagnetic coupling because the weaker interaction was observed for the shorter Mn···Mn distance.

We successfully synthesized four coordination polymers by reacting 4,4′-bpy with MnX2 where X = benzoate and isomeric o-, m-, and p-nitrobenzoates in a 1:1 molar ratio. The general formula of all four complexes are the same, [Mn(4,4′-bpy)(X)2] n , but the topologies of the polymers are very different. The species with benzoate and m-nitrobenzoate are 2D rectangular grid-like sheets; the complex with o-nitrobenzoate is a 1D molecular ladder, whereas the compound with p-nitrobenzoate is a unique 3D framework. This series of complexes clearly demonstrates that although the nitro group does not coordinate to the metal center its mere presence in the o-, m-, or p-position has a striking effect on the structure and dimensionality of the resulting coordination polymer. The participation of nitro group in l.p.···π and/or C–H···π interactions might be one of the probable reasons for the differences, but more complexes with various substituents in the phenyl ring of benzoate are needed to be characterized structurally to establish a relationship between the position of apparently innocent substituent and the topology of the polymers. This would potentially be an effective approach of controlling the dimensionality of the coordination polymers, and we will pay attention to exploit this dimension of crystal engineering as a tool for tuning the crystalline solid architecture.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We successfully synthesized four coordination polymers by reacting 4,4'-bpy with MnX2 where X = benzoate and isomeric o-, m-, and p-nitrobenzoates in a 1:1 molar ratio. The general formula of all four complexes are the same, [Mn(4,4'-bpy)(X)2] n , but the topologies of the polymers are very different. The species with benzoate and m-nitrobenzoate are 2D rectangular grid-like sheets; the complex with o-nitrobenzoate is a 1D molecular ladder, whereas the compound with p-nitrobenzoate is a unique 3D framework. This series of complexes clearly demonstrates that although the nitro group does not coordinate to the metal center its mere presence in the o-, m-, or p-position has a striking effect on the structure and dimensionality of the resulting coordination polymer. The participation of nitro group in l.p.⋅⋅⋅π and/or C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions might be one of the probable reasons for the differences, but more complexes with various substituents in the phenyl ring of benzoate are needed to be characterized structurally to establish a relationship between the position of apparently innocent substituent and the topology of the polymers. This would potentially be an effective approach of controlling the dimensionality of the coordination polymers, and we will pay attention to exploit this dimension of crystal engineering as a tool for tuning the crystalline solid architecture.

elements.content: The magnetic measurement of the species shows a weak antiferromagnetic Mn···Mn interaction which is usual for the doubly carboxylate-bridged Mn(II) complexes. The magnitudes of the J values however indicate that the syn-syn bridging mode of carboxylate is not necessarily the more efficient pathway than syn-anti. The Mn···Mn distances also do not show any meaningful relationship with the magnitude of coupling constants. Instead, other structural parameters such as the Mn–Osyn–C angle (β) may be related with the superexchange in these types of carboxylate bridges.

The Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distances also do not show any meaningful relationship with the magnitude of coupling constants. Instead, other structural parameters such as the Mn-Osyn-C angle (β) may be related with the superexchange in these types of carboxylate bridges.

cln_elements.content:
A 10 mL methanol solution of 0.820 g (5 mmol) of 4,4′-bpy was added dropwise to a stirred solution of 1.845 g (5 mmol) of Mn(C6H5COO)2·4H2O in 20 mL of CH3OH. After ca. 15 min, yellow colored solid products started to separate. The solid was filtered off after about 2 h and from the clear filtrate pale yellow platelike crystals were grown by slow evaporation at room temperature for 2–3 days.

Complex 1: Yield: 1.65 g; 73%. Anal. Calcd for C24H18MnN2O4 (453.34): C, 63.58; H, 4.00; N, 6.18 Found: C, 63.55; H, 3.97; N, 6.15. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1642 νas(COO), 1392 νs(COO) .

Complex 2: Yield: 2.06 g; 76%. Anal. Calcd for C48H32Mn2N8O16 (1086.70): C, 53.05; H, 2.97; N, 10.31 Found: C, 53.01; H, 2.93; N, 10.27. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 1612, 1531 νas(COO), 1405, 1365 νs(COO).

cln_elements.content: Spectroscopic data and their assignments are given in the . The attributions of IR spectra of all the complexes are difficult due to the appearance of several absorption bands from the secondary spacer 4,4′-bpy and the benzoate/nitro-benzoate ligands. Assignments are based on the structures of 1–4 and related complexes reported previously. In the region expected for the νas(COO–) absorption, compounds 1, 3, and 4 exhibit one single sharp and strong band at 1642, 1601, and 1667 cm–1 respectively, attributable to the presence of only one type of carboxylate bridging in the structures. While for the molecular ladder complex 2, two sharp and strong bands at 1621 and 1531 cm–1 indicate the presence of two different coordination modes of carboxylate groups. Along with these, the sharp peaks at 1392 cm–1 (for 1), 1405 cm–1 along with a shoulder at 1365 cm–1 (for 2), 1388 cm–1 (for 3), and 1397 cm–1 (for 4) appear due to the characteristic symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylates.

IR Spectra of the Complexes

Spectroscopic data and their assignments are given in the . The attributions of IR spectra of all the complexes are difficult due to the appearance of several absorption bands from the secondary spacer 4,4'-bpy and the benzoate/nitro-benzoate ligands. Assignments are based on the structures of 1-4 and related complexes reported previously. In the region expected for the νas(COO-) absorption, compounds 1, 3, and 4 exhibit one single sharp and strong band at 1642, 1601, and 1667 cm-1 respectively, attributable to the presence of only one type of carboxylate bridging in the structures. While for the molecular ladder complex 2, two sharp and strong bands at 1621 and 1531 cm-1 indicate the presence of two different coordination modes of carboxylate groups. Along with these, the sharp peaks at 1392 cm-1 (for 1), 1405 cm-1 along with a shoulder at 1365 cm-1 (for 2), 1388 cm-1 (for 3), and 1397 cm-1 (for 4) appear due to the characteristic symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylates.

| compounds | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 |
|-----------|---|---|---|---|
| C/cm³ K mol⁻¹ | 4.362(5) | 4.351(4) | 4.443(8) | 4.536(3) |
| θ/K | –16.0(2) | –4.5(2) | –17.3(3) | –10.99(9) |
| J kB⁻¹/K | –1.121(3) | –0.509(2) | –1.230(3) | –0.771(2) |
| g | 1.9856(4) | 1.980(1) | 2.0058(7) | 2.0249(7) |

a. C and θ stand for the Curie and Weiss constants, respectively.
b. J values correspond to the convention H = −2JSₐ·Sₑ for two coupled centers.
c. Landé g factor.
<END>

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Different Coordination Modes of Carboxylate Group Observed in the Literature</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-008649_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Different Coordination Modes of Carboxylate Group Observed in the Literature

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<caption>
<title>Formation of the Complexes</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr2" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2011-008649_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The coordination environments of the Mn(II) ion in complexes 1 (symmetry transformation a = –x, y, –z + 3/2, b = –x, –y + 1, –z + 2) (left) and 3 (symmetry transformation a = –x, y, –z + 3/2, b = –x, –y, –z + 2) (right) with ellipsoids at 30% probability. All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  The coordination environments of the Mn(II) ion in complexes 1 (symmetry transformation a = -x, y, -z + 3/2, b = -x, -y + 1, -z + 2) (left) and 3 (symmetry transformation a = -x, y, -z + 3/2, b = -x, -y, -z + 2) (right) with ellipsoids at 30% probability. All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (left) View of [Mn(benzoate)]∞ chain in 1 (symmetry transformation a = –x, –y + 1, –z + 2, b = –x, –y + 1, –z + 1). 4,4′-bpy and all hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity; (right) 2D layered structure of 1 along the bc plane. Phenyl ring of carboxylate ligand and all hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (left) View of [Mn(benzoate)]∞ chain in 1 (symmetry transformation a = -x, -y + 1, -z + 2, b = -x, -y + 1, -z + 1). 4,4'-bpy and all hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity; (right) 2D layered structure of 1 along the bc plane. Phenyl ring of carboxylate ligand and all hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.

cln_elements.content: The coordination environments of the Mn(II) ions in complex 2 with ellipsoids at 20% probability (symmetry transformation a = –x, −y, −z, b = –x – 1, –y, –z + 1). All hydrogen atoms and NO2 groups have been omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  The coordination environments of the Mn(II) ions in complex 2 with ellipsoids at 20% probability (symmetry transformation a = -x, -y, -z, b = -x - 1, -y, -z + 1). All hydrogen atoms and NO2 groups have been omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: View of 1-D ladder structure (left). All phenyl rings of carboxylate ligands and hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity. Formation of supramolecular network by lone pair···π interactions in complex 2 (right). All hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  View of 1-D ladder structure (left). All phenyl rings of carboxylate ligands and hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity. Formation of supramolecular network by lone pair⋅⋅⋅π interactions in complex 2 (right). All hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.

cln_elements.content: The coordination environment of the Mn(II) ion in complex 4 with ellipsoids at 30% probability(symmetry transformation a = –x + 1, y, –z + 3/2, b = –x + 1, –y, –z + 2, c = x, –y, z – 1). All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  The coordination environment of the Mn(II) ion in complex 4 with ellipsoids at 30% probability(symmetry transformation a = -x + 1, y, -z + 3/2, b = -x + 1, -y, -z + 2, c = x, -y, z - 1). All hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (A) View of doubly carboxylate-bridged [Mn(p-NO2)benzoate]]∞ chain in 4 (symmetry transformation a = –x + 1, –y, –z + 1, b = –x + 1, –y, –z + 2). 4,4′-bpy and all hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity. (B) 3D network structure of 4. All phenyl rings of carboxylate ligands and hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  (A) View of doubly carboxylate-bridged [Mn(p-NO2)benzoate]]∞ chain in 4 (symmetry transformation a = -x + 1, -y, -z + 1, b = -x + 1, -y, -z + 2). 4,4'-bpy and all hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity. (B) 3D network structure of 4. All phenyl rings of carboxylate ligands and hydrogen atoms have been removed for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Formation of supramolecular network by lone pair···π interactions in complex 4. All hydrogen atoms and 4,4′-bpy rings have been removed for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Formation of supramolecular network by lone pair⋅⋅⋅π interactions in complex 4. All hydrogen atoms and 4,4'-bpy rings have been removed for clarity.

cln_elements.content: The temperature dependences of χm T and χm –1 for randomly oriented polycrystalline specimens of 1 (a), 2 (b), 3 (c), and 4 (d). The solid lines superposed on the χm T vs T plots show the curves calculated from an infinite chain model for 1, 3, and 4 and a dinuclear model for 2. The solid lines on the χm –1 vs T plots stand for the Curie–Weiss relation. For the equations and parameters, see the text and Table .
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  The temperature dependences of χm T and χm -1 for randomly oriented polycrystalline specimens of 1 (a), 2 (b), 3 (c), and 4 (d). The solid lines superposed on the χm T vs T plots show the curves calculated from an infinite chain model for 1, 3, and 4 and a dinuclear model for 2. The solid lines on the χm -1 vs T plots stand for the Curie-Weiss relation. For the equations and parameters, see the text and Table .

metadata.title: A Unique Example of Structural Diversity Tuned by Apparently Innocent o-, m-, and p-Nitro Substituents of Benzoate in Their Complexes of Mn(II) with 4,4′-Bipyridine: 1D Ladder, 2D Sheet, and 3D Framework
